Award.AwardTitle: EMSW21-RTG: Research Training Group in Logic and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Research Training Group in logic and dynamics at the University of North Texas seeks to integrate faculty research with the training of postdoctoral associates, graduate students, and undergraduate students in mathematical sciences. The faculty associates (Gao, Jackson, Mauldin, Urbanski) in this project represent a unique blend of research interests in the areas of logic and dynamics, and in particular the exciting interactions between the two fields. The trainees in this project will be exposed to a wide range of research topics from descriptive set theory to ergodic theory, and from definable equivalence relations to infinite iterated function systems. It is expected that they will be attracted by the underlying connections among these topics, and they will make further contributions to the fields through their research.

The activities in this project include undergraduate research colloquia, supervised undergraduate research projects, research seminars, annual mini-conferences, biannual research workshops, and teaching workshops. By a thorough mentoring process and other community-building interactions, the participants of the project will experience a full range of training and will be fully supported financially, intellectually, and professionally. It is expected that the activities will produce high-quality research results on all levels. It is also expected that faculty research productivity will be enhanced because of interactions and collaborations in the project. The Research Training Group strives to increase the number of students (both graduate and undergraduate) pursuing a mathematics degree and career, and in particular to increase the number and percentage of members of underrepresented groups pursuing advanced mathematics degrees. The activities and objectives of the project are carefully designed to address the current challenges and opportunities in the North Texas region.

ProgramReference.Text: RES TRAINING GROUPS IN THE MATH SCIENCES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project faculty mentors trained postdoc, graduate, and undergraduate trainees on research and professional development through organized research activities such as seminars, colloquia, summer research programs, and research conferences. The objectives of the project were for the postdoc and graduate trainees to become researchers with expertise in logic, dynamics, and their interactions, for the undergraduate researchers to be exposed to genuine mathematical research, and in general to stimulate positive changes in the teaching and research culture at UNT and in the North Texas region.

As a result, three postdoc trainees have produced numerous high-quality publications in research and have been placed in well-respected academic jobs. Eight graduate trainees have had a successful training in research as well as in teaching. One graduate trainee has completed the PhD study and another has successfully defended dissertation. The rest of the graduate trainees are expected to finish soon. Throughout the project a total of 53 undergraduate summer research scholarships were awarded for students to participate in the Summer Undergraduate Mathematics Scholars (SUMS) program. In addition, three more students participated without financial support. The SUMS program has resulted in eight research articles submitted for publication, and four of the eight have been published in research journals. The project has brought permanent changes to the research facilities and the curriculum at UNT. The undergraduate colloquium series, first sponsored by the project, has been permanently supported by the university.

The project aimed at significantly increase the number of undergraduate students pursuing a mathematics degree and career, increase the number of women and minorities pursuing advanced degrees and careers in mathematics research and education, and increase the percentage of U.S. citizens, nationals, and permanent residents in the graduate mathematics programs at UNT. These objectives were met with the following statistics. At least 13 undergraduate students who received SUMS awards successfully graduated with a bachelor’s degree in mathematics, and all but one of them moved on to a graduate program in mathematics. Among them at least 5 have completed a Master’s degree in mathematics. During the project period the RTG faculty members have graduated 5 Master’s and 12 PhDs, among whom there were 3 PhDs and 1 Master’s from underrepresented groups. In addition, the faculty members are mentoring 14 PhD students. All 14 of them are U.S. citizens, and among them there are five from underrepresented groups.
